I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 

 
1. 
investment of up to $75,000,000 in OrbiMed Asia Partners IV, L.P. 
 
2. 
OrbiMed Asia Partners IV, L.P. (OAP IV) is a private equity fund established as a Cayman 
Islands exempted limited partnership with an expected fund size of $650 million. OrbiMed Asia 
General Partner IV, L.P., a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership, is the general partner 
of  OAP  IV.  The  adviser  of  the  general  partner  and  the  fund  manager,  OrbiMed  Advisors  LLC 
(OrbiMed), is a limited liability company incorporated in Delaware, United States (US).1 OrbiMed 
was established in  1989  and  is  one  of  the  world’s  largest  health  care-dedicated  investors  with 
about $14 billion in assets under management as of 31 March 2020.2 This is a second follow-on 
equity investment by ADB into a health care fund managed by OrbiMed.3 
 
3. 
OAP IV is expected to provide mainly growth capital to health care companies operating 
in India and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) across the biopharma, medical technology, 
health  care  services,  diagnostics,  and  distribution  subsectors.  Since  OAP  IV  is  a  health  care 
focused  fund,  no  climate  change  impact  is  expected  from  this  investment.  The  ongoing 
coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  is  driving  the  need  for  higher  health  care  capacity 
reserves and stimulating direct demand for health care services and products, as well as  hard 
and soft health infrastructure across the Asian Development Bank’s (ADBs) developing member 
countries. In this context, ADB’s proposed investment in OAP IV is expected to be highly catalytic 
in  developing  effective  long  term  solutions  and  responses  to  global  health  care  crises  by 
enhancing disease detection and treatment and response capacities in India and the PRC. 

4. 
Even  though  OAP  IV  is  a  health  care  focused  fund,  the  proposed  investment  is  not 
categorized as  a  COVID-19  response  project  because OrbiMed  did  not specifically  design  the 
fund to address COVID-19 related issues. Instead, the fund has a broader and longer-term focus 
given  its  aim  of  seeking  equity  investments  in  established  and  growing  companies  across the 
health care segment in India and PRC.  

 

  

5. 
OAP IV, however, could potentially end up supporting companies involved in COVID-19 
responses given OrbiMed’s global expertise and focus on health care. The blind pool nature of 
private  equity  funds  further  means  that  investors  in  the  fund  (including  ADB)  do  not  know  the 
composition of the OAP IV’s portfolio at the time of our investment. Therefore, it is not possible to 
estimate the COVID-19 impact of the fund’s investments ex-ante.

Asia Partners III, LP Fund (2017 vintage, $551 million) - $59.9 million commitment approved in August 2017.

8. 
Investment identification. The investment in OAP IV is a continuation of ADB’s efforts to 
increase nonsovereign financing support to the critical health care sector and an endorsement of 
OrbiMed as a strong health care partner for ADB in the Asia and Pacific region. OrbiMed is unique 
because it is the first Asian regional dedicated health care fund manager with expertise across 
the entire health care spectrum. [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception 
to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].

Advisory  committee.  In  addition  to  the  investment  committee,  OAP  IV  will  have  an 
advisory  committee  of  up  to  seven  members  representing  OAP  IV’s  limited  partners  to  be 
appointed  by  the  general  partner.  ADB  is  expected  to  be  represented  on  OAP  IV’s  advisory 
committee, which will opine on matters related to potential conflicts of interest, exercise its right 
to  consent  to  certain  matters  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  limited  partnership 
agreement, and act in an advisory role to the general partner and its advisor.

A. 
 
ADB intends to make an equity investment of up to $75 million in OAP IV, representing 
18. 
11.5%  of  the  expected  fund  size.  ADB’s  investment  will  not  exceed  25%  of  OAP  IV’s  total 
committed capital and will not result in ADB being the single largest investor in OAP IV. 
 
B. 
 
19. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)] 
 
C. 
 
20. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
21. 
Reporting  arrangements.  The  general  partner  will  be  required  to  provide  ADB  with 
unaudited  quarterly  reports,  audited  annual reports  with  financial  statements,  a fund overview, 
annual  development  effectiveness  monitoring  reports,  and  an  overview  of  the  portfolio  with 
summary information on each portfolio company’s performance. ADB will review this information 
and follow up with the general partner if more information or clarification is needed. If the information 
received from the general partner raises issues that could impair the value of ADB’s investment in 
OAP IV, ADB could decide to put OAP IV on a watch list for more frequent and detailed review. 
 
D. 
 
Catalytic anchor role. OrbiMed continues to demonstrate to institutional investors that a 
22. 
dedicated  health  care  private  equity  fund  is  an  investable  asset  in  Asia.  ADB's  ongoing 
participation in the Asia platform provides new investors with the necessary comfort and validation 
of  the  strategy,  team  and  health  care market  opportunities  in  Asia.  [This  information  has  been 
removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 
17.2.(v)]. As one of the major anchor investors, ADB’s continued support of OrbiMed provides the 
early  validation  needed  to  secure  commitments  from  such  new  institutions,  thereby  enabling 
OrbiMed to successfully raise its largest targeted Asia fund since inception in 2008. 
 
23. 
Increased  gender  inclusiveness.  OrbiMed  has  committed  to  working  with  ADB  to 
explore  and  adopt  measures  to  achieve  a more gender  equitable  work  force  at  OAP  IV.  As  a 
result, ADB aims to secure a gender categorization for the investment of some gender elements. 
 
24. 
Environmental,  social,  and  governance  standards.  ADB's  participation  will  obligate 
OrbiMed to ensure that OAP IV's investee companies comply with ADB's environment and social 
safeguard  standards,  and  to  report  on  development  indicators.  ADB's  role,  along  with  other 
members of OAP IV's advisory committee, will also be to assist in providing oversight on important 
governance  matters,  which  are  critical  for  investee  companies  to  demonstrate  as  they  seek 
additional sources of growth capital from institutional and/or individual investors. 
 
E.

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

 
A. 
 
34. 
Impact.  The  project  is  aligned  with the  following  impact:  funding  increased  to  enhance 
capacity and resilience of health care systems to fight and control pandemic outbreaks in Asia, 
particularly in India and the PRC. 
 
35.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: financial and social sustainability 
of  private  equity  investments  in  innovative  health  care  companies  demonstrated,  such  as 
companies  producing  or  distributing  essential  medicines  or  vaccines,  introducing  innovative 
medicines,  medical  devices  or  diagnostics,  or  providing  health  care  services  targeting  lower-
income segments or rural or peri-urban markets, while also generating additional employment. 
 
36.  Outputs. The outputs of the project are (i) OAP IV established and (ii) gender equality of 
OAP IV’s operations increased. 
 
B. 
 
37. 
Consistency with ADB strategy. The investment in OAP IV aligns with ADB’s Strategy 
2030  operational  priority  1,  addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  which 
mandates  ADB  to  undertake  efforts  to  contribute  to  the  overarching  goal  of  universal  health 
coverage and to generate quality jobs to support inclusive growth for all. This engagement also 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

4 

 

 5 

accelerates  progress  in  gender  equality  and  contributes  to  operational  priority  2,  accelerating 
progress in gender equality. 
 
38. 
Consistency with country strategies. The investment is consistent with ADB’s country 
partnership strategy for India, 2018–2022 and country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–
2020, which include support for the countries’ health sectors as strategic priorities. 
 
39. 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  investment  in 
OAP IV is consistent with ADB’s operational plan for health, which strongly supports private sector 
approaches to improve quality, affordability, and accessibility in the health sector.5 
 
40. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 

 
A. 
 
41. 
Statement (2009).6 
 
42. 
Category  FI.  ADB  has  assessed  the  investment's  potential  environmental  and  social 
impacts,  its risks  associated  with  OrbiMed’s  existing  and  likely  OAP IV future portfolio,  and  its 
commitment and capacity for environmental and social management. During due diligence, ADB 
has identified the following actions to enhance the environmental and social management system 
(ESMS):  improve  the  pre-capital  call  process  for  investment  screening  notification  to  ADB, 
develop  subsector-specific  environmental  risk  and  regulatory  compliance  screening  checklists, 
implement a training plan based on identified needs of the OAP IV investment team, and refine 
annual  environmental  and  social  performance  reporting.  OrbiMed  has  agreed  to  required 
enhancements to the ESMS and such will be applied prior to first capital call for an investment. 
OrbiMed will (i) apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list, (ii) ensure that investments using 
ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by applicable national laws 
and regulations, and (iii) establish and maintain an appropriate ESMS satisfactory to ADB before 
disbursement.7 The ESMS will set out requirements, as applicable, for compliance with national 
labor  laws  and  measures  to  comply  with  the  internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards, 
pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy. ADB will retain the right to opt out of contributing 
capital to any investment categorized as A, and any investment categorized as B for involuntary 
resettlement  or  indigenous  peoples  impacts.  The  ESMS  will  also  contain  requirements,  as 
applicable,  for  information  disclosure  and consultation with  affected  people in  accordance  with 
ADB requirements. OrbiMed will include in its annual reporting information to ADB (i) the nature 
of  subprojects  and  categorization,  (ii)  compliance  with  the  safeguard  and  social  requirements, 
and (iii) compliance with applicable national and international laws and standards. 
 

 

4  ADB.  2017.  Country  Partnership  Strategy:  India,  2018–2022—Accelerating  Inclusive  Economic  Transformation. 
Manila;  and  ADB.  2016.  Country  Partnership  Strategy:  People’s  Republic  of  China,  2016–2020—Transforming 
Partnership: People’s Republic of China and Asian Development Bank. Manila.  

5  ADB. 2015. Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020: Health in Asia and Pacific: A Focused Approach to Address the 

Health Needs of ADB Developing Member Countries. Manila.

Findings and Details of Arrangement (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 Anticorruption Policy 

Some  gender  elements.  Women  are  significantly  underrepresented  among  the 
43. 
investment decision-makers at private equity and venture capital firms in Asia where women make 
up only 18% of employees on average and hold just 12% of senior roles.8 OrbiMed’s Asia platform 
is a notable exception with 35% of its 17 staff, and 20% of its senior positions held by women.9 
OrbiMed  has  a  policy  on  preventing  sexual  harassment  that  applies  globally.  Following  ADB’s 
Policy  on  Gender  and  Development  (1998),  OAP  IV  has  incorporated  measures  to  promote 
gender equality and women’s empowerment. Key features of the gender actions are (i) promoting 
at least one female staff member to vice-president or senior associate; (ii) starting a mentorship 
program in OrbiMed’s Asia offices that includes at least 50% of female investment professionals; 
and (iii) recruiting a female lead in India for environmental, social, and governance issues. OAP 
IV will submit periodic reports on its implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B. 
 
44.  OAP IV was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C. 
 
45. 
single exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D. 
 
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),10 
46. 
ADB will proceed with the assistance  upon establishing that the governments of ADB member 
countries  where  OAP  IV  will  invest  using  ADB  finance  have  no  objection  to  the  proposed 
assistance to OAP IV. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 

The proposed equity investment is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and 

Investment Limitations 

Assurances 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
47. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $75,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in OrbiMed Asia 
Partners IV, L.P., with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 

Masatsugu Asakawa 
President

B. 

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1. OAP IV established  
1.1  Execute ADB’s legal documentation by Q4 2020. 
1.2  OAP IV establishes an independent advisory committee (with ADB representation) by Q4 2020. 
1.3  ADB and other investors invest in OAP IV by final closing in Q4 2020. 
1.4  OAP IV invests in suitable companies. 
 
2. Gender equality of OAP IV’s operations increased 
2.1 Identify a high-performing female staff member and promote her by Q4 2024. 
2.2 Design a mentorship program and commence mentorship for first female staff member by Q4 2022. 
2.3 Undertake a recruitment process for environmental, social, and governance role in India and recruit 

a suitably qualified woman by Q4 2022. 

Inputs 

ADB: Up to $75 million (equity) 
Other cofinanciers (including general partner’s contribution: $575 million (equity) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 

Not applicable 

ADB = Asian Development Bank, L.P. = limited partnership, OAP IV = OrbiMed Asia Partners IV, L.P., Q = quarter. 
a  Targeting low-income segments means that (i) the majority of products manufactured are sold at lower price than that 
available in the market from competitors, or (ii) the majority of people reached by health services provided belong to 
the five lowest-income deciles.  
Source: Asian Development Bank.
